headline.main: Abortion, Insurance and Health Care Reform
headline.print_headline: Abortion, Insurance and Health Care Reform

docs.lead_paragraph: IN New York City, where the unemployment rate remains at 10.3 percent, the jobless have started leaning hard on coffee shops and bookstores to get out of their tiny one-bedrooms and away from their annoying roommates. In these harsh, career-vanishing times, the members of this laptop brigade do everything they can to re-create the office environment they no longer have to complain about. How welcome they are varies. Some small coffeehouses have unplugged the wireless, nailed covers over electrical outlets and posted signs requesting no computer use during lunch. But the New York Public Library has kindly extended its hours at many branches, and behemoths like Starbucks and Barnes & Noble can afford to be more accommodating. At an overcrowded Midtown coffee shop, a barista recently made a woman a cup of coffee, then watched her set up a keyboard, put on headphones and start practicing piano. She's not the only one working in public. Here are portraits of four other New Yorkers trying to get back to the comfort of their offices:
docs.abstract: Deirdre Dolan and Jennifer Daniel Op-Art about four unemployed New Yorkers who sit for hours in coffee shops with their laptops trying to recreate office environment they no longer have to complain about (M)

byline.original: By DEIRDRE DOLAN and JENNIFER DANIEL

docs.lead_paragraph: An item in the Prescriptions column on Friday reported the financial problems that pregnancy-related medical bills have posed for Adrienne Schroeder, a young mother of two children, despite having had insurance coverage through her husband's employer or, now, under a plan the Schroeders bought on their own. Here is an sampling of readers' replies: The article describes a very common situation for those not in group plans. As a former sales rep for individual health plans, I used a 145-page guide of exclusions for pre-existing conditions, ''hazardous'' activities and occupations, out-of-limit weight, and use of certain medications. Many of my friends who are covered by company group plans just don't understand the high cost exposure potential and the exorbitant premiums of individual plans which still don't provide coverage for many illnesses. Many holders of such plans are covered for the catastrophic costs, but are reluctant to get the colonoscopy or the CT scans recommended by the doctor because of high deductibles. Not much chance for prevention when you can't afford to pay for it.
docs.abstract: Sampling of readers' replies to Nov 27 item in Prescription column about financial problems that pregnancy-related medical bills have posed for young mother, Adrienne Schroeder, despite her husband's health insurance coverage; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When an epidemic like the swine flu strikes, each one of us wants to know our personal risk for illness, and genetics may tell us why H1N1 hits some people so badly.

byline.original: By JEROME GROOPMAN   and PAMELA HARTZBAND

docs.lead_paragraph: Adrienne Schroeder recently moved to Richmond, Va., from Bozeman, Mont., to care for her aging father. Medical expenses -- not his, but hers -- are a concern. Ms. Schroeder had four pregnancies in the last six years, two ending in miscarriages. She still owes money from those medical costs, despite having had health insurance the whole time.
docs.abstract: Having health insurance does not preclude worrying about medical expenses; Adrienne Schroeder still owes money from previous pregnancy, despite having had health insurance; now out of work, she and husband pay $400 per month for private plan plus deductible of several thousand dollars; couple constantly looks for ways to cut medical costs; photo (S)
